title: You've got to understand rocks if you want to run BHP
text:
Mr Mackenzie's academic background is well suited to a mining and energy company; he studied geology and chemistry through a science degree at Scotland's St Andrews University.

He followed that with a PhD in organic chemistry at Bristol University, where he made discoveries that benefited the oil industry.

While Mr Mackenzie will not alone select his replacement, at BHP it is considered part of the CEO's responsibility to ensure there is a strong field of internal candidates from which to choose.

Minerals Australia boss Mike Henry and chief financial officer Peter Beaven have long been viewed as the main contenders, while Minerals America boss Danny Malchuk has increasingly been seen as a contender as well.

Mr Mackenzie's comments do not particularly boost nor condemn any of those internal candidates in comparison to each other.

Mr Beaven is a chartered accountant but has served as president of manganese and president of copper during his time at BHP.

Mr Henry began his job in logistics with Mitsubishi, and was in charge of selling BHP's products as chief marketing officer before running the Australian coal division and eventually the entire suite of Australian mines.

Mr Malchuk is an industrial engineer by training, and added an MBA to that before running BHP's aluminium, manganese, nickel and eventually copper businesses.

"What we do as a board, and what we've been doing since I became chairman, so that's over the last two years, is we have identified a profile of what we think the next CEO should look like," said Ken MacKenzie on Thursday evening, after BHP's annual meeting of shareholders in London.

"And we're benchmarking all the internal candidates against that profile, identifying gaps, putting in place development programs, and then working with our internals around closing the gaps."

BHP wants half its staff to be female by 2025, but the company indicated on Thursday night it was more focused on gender balance across its executive ranks than any individual position.

''You can't actually split an individual appointment and make it half-woman and half-man. Ultimately you're going to have to choose one or the other, but we're 50-50 in the top team," said Andrew Mackenzie, in reference to the 10-person executive leadership team that sits below him.

One highly rated, female, external option, Shell's Zoe Yujnovich, appears to be off the market after winning a big promotion to Shell headquarters at The Hague earlier this month.

A former Rio Tinto executive, Ms Yujnovich has been Shell's Australian chairman for just 30 months but will in January start a global role as Shell's executive vice-president of conventional oil and gas.

Advertisement

"In terms of the external market, we keep our eye on the external market as part of the process as well," said Ken MacKenzie on Thursday.

The chairman didn't give any sense that a change of CEO might be imminent.

"Like any board, our most important task is planning for the succession of our CEO. So it's our normal process, and it's an ongoing process," Mr MacKenzie said.

BHP's Australian shareholders will get a chance to front the board when the company holds its annual meeting of Australian shareholders in Sydney on November 7.
description: BHP chief executive Andrew Mackenzie believes his successor must have a detailed understanding of minerals and geology.
